Callbacks#

class bert_squeeze.utils.callbacks.checkpointing.CheckpointEveryNSteps(save_step_frequency: int, prefix: str = 'N-Step-Checkpoint', use_model_checkpoint_filename: bool = False)[source]#

Save a checkpoint every N steps, instead of Lightning’s default that checkpoints based on validation loss.

Parameters:

  • save_step_frequency (int) – how often to save in steps

  • prefix (str) – add a prefix to the name, only used when use_model_checkpoint_filename=False

  • use_model_checkpoint_filename (bool) – just default filename, don’t use ours.

on_batch_end(trainer: Trainer, _) → None[source]#

Check if we should save a checkpoint after every train batch

Parameters:

trainer (pl.Trainer) –

class bert_squeeze.utils.callbacks.fastbert_logic.FastBertLogic(freeze_at_epoch: int = 10)[source]#

Callback freezing the model backbone after ‘freeze_at_epoch’ epochs.

The finetune_function method is called on every train epoch start and should be used to unfreeze any parameters. Those parameters need to be added in a new param_group within the optimizer.

Parameters:

freeze_at_epoch (int) – number of epochs after which to freeze the model’s backbone

finetune_function(pl_module: LightningModule, current_epoch: int, optimizer: Optimizer, optimizer_idx: int) → None[source]#

Called when the epoch begins

Parameters:

  • pl_module (pl.LightningModule) –

  • current_epoch (int) – current epoch we are in

  • optimizer (Optimizer) – optimizer used for training

  • optimizer_idx (int) – index of the optimizer to use

freeze_before_training(pl_module: LightningModule) → None[source]#
Parameters:

pl_module –

class bert_squeeze.utils.callbacks.lottery_ticket.LotteryTicket(normalize_by_layer: bool = False, normalize_global_importance: bool = False, masking_threshold: float = 0.9, masking_amount: float = 0.1, metric: str = 'acc')[source]#
Parameters:

  • normalize_by_layer (bool) – normalize importance score by layers

  • normalize_global_importance (bool) – normalize all importance scores between 0 and 1

  • masking_threshold (float) – masking threshold in terms of metrics (stop masking when metric < threshold * original metric value)

  • masking_amount (float) – Amount of heads to mask at each masking step

compute_heads_importance(model: LightningModule, eval_dataloader: DataLoader, compute_entropy: bool = True, compute_importance: bool = True, head_mask: Tensor | None = None, actually_pruned: bool = False) → Tuple[Tensor, Tensor, Tensor, array][source]#

This method shows how to compute: - head attention entropy - head importance scores according to https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.10650

Parameters:

  • model (pl.LightningModule) – lightning model for which to compute heads importance

  • eval_dataloader (DataLoader) – dataloader to use to compute the heads importance

  • compute_entropy (bool) – whether to compute the entropy of every attention layer

  • compute_importance (bool) – whether to compute the importance of every attention layer

  • head_mask (torch.Tensor) –

  • actually_pruned (bool) –

Returns:

computed entropy for every attention layer torch.Tensor:

computed head importance of every head

torch.Tensor:

model’s predictions

np.array:

ground truth labels

Return type:

torch.Tensor

static entropy(p: Tensor) → float[source]#

Computes the entropy of a probability distribution which represents the expected amount of information drawn from that distribution.

Parameters:

p (torch.Tensor) – tensor of probabilities

Returns:

entropy value

Return type:

float

mask_heads(model: LightningModule, eval_dataloader: DataLoader) → Tensor[source]#

This method shows how to mask head (set some heads to zero), to test the effect on the network, based on the head importance scores, as described in Michel et al. (http://arxiv.org/abs/1905.10650)

Parameters:

  • model (pl.LightningModule) – model to use

  • eval_dataloader (DataLoader) – dataloader to use to mask heads

Returns:

boolean mask for which heads to prune and not to prune

Return type:

torch.Tensor

on_fit_end(trainer: Trainer, pl_module: LightningModule) → None[source]#

Method called at the end of training to prune the model’s heads.

Parameters:

  • trainer (pl.Trainer) – lightning trainer

  • pl_module (pl.LightningModule) – lightning module

static print_2d_tensor(tensor: Tensor) → None[source]#

Print a 2D tensor

Parameters:

tensor (torch.Tensor) – tensor to print

prune_heads(model: LightningModule, eval_dataloader: DataLoader, head_mask: Tensor | None = None) → None[source]#

This method shows how to prune head (remove heads weights) based on the head importance scores as described in Michel et al. (http://arxiv.org/abs/1905.10650)

Parameters:

  • model (pl.LightningModule) – model to use

  • eval_dataloader (DataLoader) – dataloader to use to mask heads

  • head_mask (torch.Tensor) – boolean mask for which heads to prune and not to prune

class bert_squeeze.utils.callbacks.pruning.SparsityBasedPruning(sparsity_level: float = 0.0, layers_to_exclude: List[str] | None = None, *args: Any, **kwargs: Any)[source]#

Callback to achieve a given level of sparsity.

Given a level of sparsity x it will prune n weights to such that (x * n)% of the model weights are pruned.

on_fit_end(trainer: Trainer, pl_module: LightningModule) → None[source]#

Method called when fit ends.

Parameters:

  • trainer (pl.Trainer) – Lightning trainer

  • pl_module (pl.LightningModule) – Lightning module

class bert_squeeze.utils.callbacks.pruning.ThresholdBasedPruning(threshold: float, start_pruning_epoch: int = 10, *args: Any, **kwargs: Any)[source]#
Callback for a very simple pruning strategy using weights magnitude like the following:
f(wi)= {wi: if |wi| > thresh

0: if |wi| ≤ thresh}

Parameters:

  • threshold (float) – value below which weights will be pruned

  • start_pruning_epoch (int) – epoch from which to apply the pruning strategy

on_before_optimizer_step(trainer: Trainer, pl_module: LightningModule, optimizer: Optimizer, optimizer_idx: int) → None[source]#

Method called before optimizer.step() to zero prune gradients

Parameters:

  • trainer (pl.Trainer) – Lightning trainer

  • pl_module (pl.LightningModule) – Lightning module

  • optimizer (Optimizer) – optimizer used for training

  • optimizer_idx (int) – index of the optimizer to use

on_fit_end(trainer: Trainer, pl_module: LightningModule) → None[source]#

Method called when fit ends.

Parameters:

  • trainer (pl.Trainer) – Lightning trainer

  • pl_module (pl.LightningModule) – Lightning module

on_train_epoch_end(trainer: Trainer, pl_module: LightningModule) → None[source]#

Method called at the end of a training epoch to prune the model.

Parameters:

  • trainer (pl.Trainer) – Lightning trainer

  • pl_module (pl.LightningModule) – Lightning module

class bert_squeeze.utils.callbacks.quantization.DynamicQuantization(layers_to_quantize: Iterable[str], *args: Any, **kwargs: Any)[source]#

Callback to convert a float model to a dynamic (i.e. weights-only) quantized model at the end of training. It uses a PyTorch util function to achieve so ([see here](https://pytorch.org/docs/stable/generated/torch.quantization.quantize_dynamic.html#torch.quantization.quantize_dynamic))

Parameters:

layer_to_quantize (Iterable[str]) – list of submodule names to apply dynamic quantization to

on_fit_end(trainer: Trainer, pl_module: LightningModule) → None[source]#

Called when fit ends.

class bert_squeeze.utils.callbacks.quantization.TransformerQAT(observer_type: str = 'average', only_last_epoch: bool = False, layers_to_fuse: List[str] | None = None)[source]#

Extends pytorch_lightning.callbacks.QuantizationAwareTraining

Quantization allows speeding up inference and decreasing memory requirements by performing computations and storing tensors at lower bitwidths (such as INT8 or FLOAT16) than floating point precision. We use native PyTorch API so for more information see PyTorch Quantization.

Parameters:

  • observer_type (str) – allows switching between MovingAverageMinMaxObserver as “average” (default) and HistogramObserver as “histogram” which is more computationally expensive.

  • only_last_epoch (bool) – whether to only perform QAT on the last epoch or not

  • layers_to_fuse (List[str]) – allows you fuse a few layers together as shown in diagram to find which layer types can be fused, check https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/pull/43286.
